intro: Phlox douglasii var. rigida, commonly known as rigid phlox, is a perennial flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Polemoniaceae family and is characterized by its upright, woody stems and dense clusters of showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing vibrant pink or purple flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and xeriscaping. Its compact growth habit and drought tolerance contribute to its adaptability in arid and semi-arid environments.
